content: ...now, with ~300 comments here, the question is "where do I start?" :sweat_smile:
...I'll go through the various chats here, then watch the weekly videos, then head to my favorite place, the issue queue :smile:
...just finished going through all the topics/comments. Taking a break now, so that I can focus on issues, then reviewing PRs by others, then taking a look at feedback on my own PRs.

If you are interested in writing another blog post, there are some misconceptions about Backdrop in here :) https://www.kalamuna.com/news/say-goodbye-drupal-7-and-hello-other-opportunities

Say Goodbye to Drupal 7 and Hello to Other Opportunities
“Whenever you see a successful business, someone once made a courageous decision.” ― Peter F. Drucker  Whether you love it, hate it, or feel nothing about it. Whether you use it every day, or only sporadically, it’s become part of your work environment. Whatever your relationship to it is, you must surely feel something as it approaches the end of its life and you need to decide what to do about it. It’s your Drupal 7 site and it sunsets next year.
Thanks @jenlampton ...I'll definitely have a look at that, and either respond there if I find a way, or write a blog post on our site ...or both :smile:
@jenlampton they have comments disabled on their blog posts, and their contact form requires a US phone number :disappointed: ...perhaps @Mike McCaffrey can liaise?
Perhaps! I tweeted at them... we'll see if that works.
Maybe we can talk about the article on Thursday, I didn't think it was very bad.
It wasn't! I added it to the external mentions page :)

It wasn't bad, but certain things need clarification/amendment. Like:

It is important to understand that Backdrop CMS is a fork and not long-term support.

...also:

...Backdrop is not Drupal and comes with hidden costs.

...and:

...new features and approaches will add to the maintenance complexity.
Personally, I don't feel the urgent need to correct those things. They are just one writers opinions. But, I understand the desire to clarify.
Sorry for not seeing this until now! It looks like Jen and Anya are talking about things on twitter.
Let me know if there is anything else you'd like me to non-publically communicate.
Article looks fair to me

Thanks @Mike McCaffrey ...and hello btw :smile: :wave: ...my main concern was that this "It is important to understand that Backdrop CMS is a fork and not long-term support." sentence may be interpreted as "Backdrop is only a temporary solution - not here to stay" kinda thing. ...unfortunately, I am not on social media like twitter/facebook/etc. so I can't follow the discussion, but I trust @jenlampton and others that are using these platforms :sweat_smile:
...and "Backdrop is not Drupal and comes with hidden costs." ...well, Drupal also comes with hidden costs - not sure why say that only specifically for Backdrop in that comparison article :shrug:

...same with "new features and approaches will add to the maintenance complexity." ...if new features in Backdrop add to maintenance complexity, then so will they for Drupal 8/9/10, and any other product really :shrug: ...my reaction to these phrases comes from an article I once read many many years ago, where article authors (for whatever reason) may use words/phrases with negative meaning/connotations, without giving actual arguments. If there is nothing substantial to support a claim, then best left unsaid/unwritten I say.

@Mike McCaffrey if you could convey that we all really liked the article (or at least @klonos and I both mentioned it earlier) I don't want us all to get bogged down in the details :) We should say the positive things too!
:+1:
